description: A major selling point of this “Camelot” is the chance to hear this winning 1960 score sumptuously performed by the New York Philharmonic under the musical theater maestro Paul Gemignani.
title: ‘Camelot,’ With the Philharmonic Playing Along
title_page: ‘Camelot,’ With the Philharmonic Playing Along - The New York Times
maintext:
The New York Philharmonic calls its charming performance of Lerner and Loewe’s “Camelot,” which opened on Wednesday night before an adoring audience, a semistaged production. Actually the staging is fairly elaborate.
The cast performs atop a makeshift raked platform that extends into the Avery Fisher Hall auditorium, covering about half a dozen rows of seats up front, with the orchestra of nearly 60 performing from the rear of the stage. At one point a circular section of the platform rises dramatically to become the round table where the idealistic King Arthur gathers his legendary knights.
With colorful costumes, rosters of dancers and thrusting sword-fight scenes, the production, directed by Lonny Price and choreographed by Josh Prince, is no less intricate than, say, the staging for the Broadway hit “Chicago.”
